text: stretching before our workout is a
little controversial there are studies
that have shown that stretching can be
beneficial there are ones that show it's
really not effective and there's no
conclusive research that supports it and
then there are studies that show that it
should be detrimental the thought is
that when you stretch a muscle it can
reduce force production for up to an
hour after you stretch so during a
sporting activity you need maximal force
production I do recommend that athletes
do more dynamic stretches as opposed to
static stretches so that your muscles
getting used to going through the
movement that you're gonna do so for
example if you are a track runner get
the muscles lengthened and ready to to
activate but static stretching I don't
really recommend to my athletes before
they do sporting activities stretching
you can actually lengthen the muscle
better when it's warmed up and
stretching has been shown to be optimal
at 30 minutes after an activity so I
tell people like cooldown relax with
your teammates and then when you get
back into the locker room of the
training room that's the optimal time to
stretch for you and that's when you
could do your more static prolonged
stretching stretching the long term has
been shown to be beneficial because it
can do three things it can increase
force production it can increase power
and it can also increase jumping height
if you don't stretch for a week and then
you go back and stretch you'll be amazed
at how much your muscles have tightened
up so I tell people at least five days a
week they need to be stretching
